body: Related discussion in tensorflow https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/1592.

@vchuravy 
Thanks for your advance.

**Platform**: Ubuntu 14.04 64-bits 
 **MXNet Version** : 0.0.8(comes from julia's Pkg.installed(),but I compiled `libmxnet.so` manually from `github` this week which I guess being latest,is that?)
**Graphic Card**: GTX 760 (4GB)

**Code Example**:

> using MXNet
> ctx=mx.gpu();
> gpu_w=mx.rand(0,1,( 7000,9600),ctx);
> const iter=6;
> const sub_iter=30;
> 
> for i=1:iter
> println("$i loop");
>    for sub_i=1:sub_iter
>        gpu_dw1=gpu_w._(1-mx.sign(gpu_w));
>         copy(gpu_dw1);   #  *_if you comment this line**,you would like to get sth. like **Error**
> end
> end

**Error**:

> [07:53:11] /home/chen/bin/mxnet/dmlc-core/include/dmlc/./logging.h:235: [07:53:11] src/storage/./gpu_device_storage.h:39: Check failed: e == cudaSuccess || e == cudaErrorCudartUnloading CUDA: out of memory

If you do not know what caused this error, you can try set environment variable MXNET_ENGINE_TYPEto NaiveEngine and run with debugger (i.e. gdb). This will force all operations to be synchronous and backtrace will give you the series of calls that lead to this error. Remember to set MXNET_ENGINE_TYPE back to empty after debugging.

**NOTE**:
 `/home/chen/bin/mxnet` is downloaded from `github`,NOT from julia's `Pkg`.

I'll appreciate any suggestion from you.

Thank you very much! It's too complex,can you give me a contact number,like wechat or phone number,I can consult effectively. I think the most difficult to use mxnet is that examples of api are limited. @Ldpe2G @piiswrong
It's just for reporting

Sometimes the interaction between GC and GPU memory can be troublesome. We only release memory when the Julia values are gc'd and your code is creating a large amount of copies and you are running out of memory because of that.

Additionally the code you are using creates a few temporaries arrays that then need to be garbage collected, amplifying the problem. `gpu_w` and `gpu_dw1` together use about 600MBs and one iteration of your code allocates atleast 800MB for temporaries.

From my understanding of MXNet.jl we currently don't have to many inplace operators defined for NDArrays to do such computations and mainly rely on MXNet graph based execution to do those optimizations. So you might have more luck expressing this in terms of the symbolic API.

See the latter part of http://mxnetjl.readthedocs.org/en/latest/user-guide/overview.html for a discussion of inplace operations (low-level API) and the symbolic API.

The difference seems to be i386 vs x86_64 during compilation for iPhone 5 and iPhone 6 respectively.
Solved!  The bugs lie in the latest ipykernel of version 4.3.1. After backtracking to version 4.2.2, everything works fine.

I got a prototype working with small data set, but got time-out when file size exceeds 1G, which I am thinking whether it's right approach to train 2T data set hosted in AWS. Currently, we attached big hard disks to work around this issue. Sorry having little time on this for now, but will look at it when I am free if nobody have a fix on it.

This way is too complex. It seems we should control the detailed process of forward and backward.
How about fit ？ Can we directly use fit，because fit also has a parameter "optimizer". @Ldpe2G @piiswrong
model.fit(X = train, eval_data = val,
          batch_end_callback = mx.callback.Speedometer(batch_size=batch_size),
          epoch_end_callback = checkpoint)

A `transpose` symbolic operator has been added in the upstream (libmxnet) recently. I guess we should be able to use it automatically (need to update the doc).

For the backward, if your graph contains a loss node at the top, then it should be fine. Otherwise, you need to have some kinds of `output_error` or `out_grad` to allow it to do a chain-rule to back-propagate. The computed gradients are stored in `executor.grad_arrays`.
Yes you can. You can checkout the `__iter__` function in the [bucket-io.py](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/rnn/bucket_io.py#L200) for example, it uses the generator.
I see MXPredPartialForward was added to code base, but not see where to use it.
see last block of https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/notebooks/predict-with-pretrained-model.ipynb  get_internals allows you to get any internal symbols
put all the training rec files in a folder say `mydata`, and put it under your data folder, set `--train-dataset` to mydata should do the job
Yes, it's what I am looking for. Thanks so much!

No it is for single machine so far. Usually we want to use data par between machines, as copy state is more costly than copy params. A copy operator is inserted between layers with different devices.

BTW: @yzhang87 after #1938 is merged, we can then set `use_ignore=True` and `ignore_label=0` to ignore the padded examples in bucketing. Make sure to distinguish between padding and silence in this case.

New operator `mxnet.symbol.ROIPooling` is slightly tricky. Here are some key information that are missing from documentation.

``` python
import mxnet as mx
data = mx.sym.Variable('data')
# [batch_size, channel, height, width]
rois = mx.sym.Variable('rois')
# [roi_number, 5]
# last dimension is [batch index of image, x1, y1, x2, y2]
# some convolutional layer
roi_pool = mx.sym.ROIPooling(data=data, rois=rois, pooled_size=(6, 6), spatial_scale=0.0625)
# please note that batch_size changes from batch_size to roi_number after ROI pooling.
```
@precedenceguo  How to train network with `mxnet.symbol.ROIPooling`? Any example?

I noticed that the [executor_manager.DataParallelExecutorGroup](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/executor_manager.py#L230) uses the same `slices` for both input data and labels. But in the case of fast-rcnn, during training, the input images are in shape `(2,3,H,W)` while the labels' are `(128,) for the 128 ROIS`. How can we change the code for training?
Because of my carelessness,  I forgot to set `round_batch=False` in test iterator.

Multiple devices training split data into slices for devices. In this example, each data batch has image shape `(2, 3, H, W)` and label shape `(128, )`. Splitting data batches does not compromise each batch since loader supply data and label together in each batch. Therefore no change is necessary except the number of training devices. For the training of Fast R-CNN, it is recommended to see the [original caffe version](https://github.com/rbgirshick/py-faster-rcnn) for now.

I'm not using multiple devices for training. I use the python api [`model.fit`](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/model.py#L694) which actually calls `_train_multi_device`. The [executor_manager](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/executor_manager.py#L230) inside `_train_multi_device` uses the same `slices` for both input data and labels. It works for the case where the batch sizes are the same for both input data and label. I'm looking for advice on how to change the code accordingly when input data and label have different batch sizes.
There could exist some issue about varying batch size with the FeedForward API. Is there any error message or anomaly?

power is underscored because it only takes two ndarray as input, there are other two functions, _power_scalar, _rpower_scalar that defines power over scalar. So overriding in language native side is needed.

log is already defined https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/elementwise_unary_op-inl.h#L127

I see. So we should really have some kind of "dispatch" function that calls corresponding implementation.

Or can we have a "broadcast" behavior by default just like numpy ufunc?
Yes,currently we need somekind of dispatch function for this. For power, as we have to do operator overloading anyway, so it is fine.

Could it be possible to view this single machine as one device(or more) with full model by adding kvstore? I think it is possible to follow the update_on_kvstore function on manipulating arg_list and grad_list. The list shape will be the same, while the ctxs are disordered.

I prefer realtime too. My solution is to set auto_reset=True in metric
